awd_titl_txt: I-Corps: Manufacturing miniaturized high density printed circuit boards
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of a novel printed circuit board (PCB) laser micromachining processes. Conventional PCB manufacturing processes utilize wet chemical etching and electroless deposition. These conventional processes require the use of many hazardous chemicals, heated etching baths, and multiple washing cycles requiring excessive water use.  The proposed miniaturized PCBs can be used in space-constrained electronics devices such as mobile, wearable, and implantable medical devices to make them lighter and more compact, creating additional room for a battery at reduce cost.

This I-Corps project is focused on the development of novel low-cost printed circuit board (PCB) manufacturing technology that produces PCBs with higher wiring density than conventional PCB, reducing the PCB size.  The proposed PCB manufacturing technology uses laser-micromachining, a chemical-free process that eliminates the use of harsh chemicals and reduces water and electricity consumption.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Throughout the I-Corps program, extensive customer interviews provided crucial insights into market demands, identifying three key areas: 1) Miniaturized electronics for mobile and wearable devices, 2) High-density PCBs as a cost-effective alternative to semiconductor packaging substrates, and 3) High-density PCBs tailored for the DIY and maker community. Furthermore, we identified three potential customer segments: 1) Device manufacturers pioneering the next generation of wearable devices, 2) Custom Application Specific Integrated Circuit (ASIC) developers, and 3) Enthusiasts within the DIY community seeking high-density PCB solutions. We also executed nondisclosure agreements (NDAs) with three customers from these segments, solidifying the commercial viability of our technology.

The I-Corps program also proved instrumental in refining our business model, pinpointing key value propositions, revenue streams, and distribution channels. This iterative process empowered us to develop a more resilient and effective strategy for bringing our technology to market. Throughout our customer interactions, we fostered connections with a diverse network of mentors, industry experts, investors, and potential collaborators. Leveraging these relationships, we initiated a promising collaboration with the City of Columbus, GA, laying the groundwork for establishing our inaugural pilot manufacturing facility in the region.

Armed with validated market data, a refined business model, and a solid go-to-market plan, the team successfully secured pre-seed funding from reputable VC firms. Additionally, we earned a position in the START.nano incubator program, providing us with discounted access to nanofabrication tools, and gained admission to Georgia's esteemed technology business incubator, the Advanced Technology Development Center (ATDC), which offers invaluable entrepreneurship mentorship. Moreover, our team's accomplishments were acknowledged as finalists in both the Lam Capital Venture Competition and the Activate 2023 Fellowship.


Last Modified: 03/17/2024
Modified by: Neil A Gershenfeld
